{
  "question": "A perfectly flexible uniform chain of total mass $m = 18.0~\\mathrm{kg}$ and length $L = 12.0~\\mathrm{m}$ rests fully coiled atop a frictionless platform of mass $M = 38.0~\\mathrm{kg}$ at initial height $H = 31.0~\\mathrm{m}$ above the ground. At time $t = 0$, the platform is released from rest and descends vertically under the action of gravity, but its downward acceleration is held constant at $a = 1.90~\\mathrm{m/s}^2$ by an external, precisely controlled mechanism. The platform's motion is not influenced by the changing load of the chain. As the platform descends, the chain unwraps at a constant rate (as measured in the ground frame): at any time $t$, the length of chain hanging straight down from the platform is $\\ell(t) = (L/T) t$, where $T$ is the total time required for the full chain to uncoil, and $\\ell(0) = 0$. The uncoiling rate $L/T$ is constant, and $T$ is explicitly given: $T = 4.00~\\mathrm{s}$. Assume the hanging chain always remains vertical, and neglect air resistance.\n\nAt time $t_1 = T/2 = 2.00~\\mathrm{s}$ (when exactly half the chain by length and mass is hanging), an ideal, instantaneous explosion splits the hanging portion exactly at its midpoint. Each resulting fragment, of mass $m/4$ and length $L/4$, receives an additional horizontal velocity $\\Delta v = 7.20~\\mathrm{m/s}$ in the $+x$ and $-x$ directions, respectively, in the ground frame, perpendicular to gravity. Immediately after the explosion, the remainder of the chain on the platform is fixed rigidly to it; the explosion exerts no impulse or recoil on the platform or the secured chain. The vertical velocities of all parts remain unchanged at the instant of the explosion.\n\nGiven $g = 9.81~\\mathrm{m/s^2}$, calculate the horizontal distance $\\Delta x$ in meters between the landing points of the two chain fragments on the ground. Express your final answer as $\\boxed{\\Delta x = ~~~\\mathrm{m}}$.",
  "topic_tags": [
    "Mechanics",
    "Projectile Motion",
    "Variable Mass Systems",
    "Explosions",
    "Kinematics",
    "Reference Frames"
  ]
}

{
  "question": "A solid homogeneous disk of mass $M = 6.20~\\mathrm{kg}$ and radius $R = 0.210~\\mathrm{m}$ is rigidly fixed to rotate frictionlessly on a horizontal axle through its center. A flexible, massless rope is wound $n=5$ times around the disk's perimeter, so that when the free end is pulled vertically downward by a compact mass $m = 1.30~\\mathrm{kg}$, the rope maintains taut contact and the disk rotates without slip. The system starts from rest, with the mass positioned $h = 3.00~\\mathrm{m}$ vertically above the ground. Neglect the mass of both rope and coil in all calculations.\n\nFirmly attached to the rope at a point immediately below the disk is a rigid rectangular copper coil with $N=1500$ identical turns, each of area $A=a b$ where $a=0.140~\\mathrm{m}$ and $b=0.070~\\mathrm{m}$. The coil's total electrical resistance is $R = 12.0~\\Omega$ and its self-inductance is $L = 32.0~\\mathrm{mH}$. As the mass descends, the coil moves vertically, always remaining aligned horizontally (its plane is normal to $\\hat{z}$), and maintains pure translation relative to the ground. Initially, the center of the coil is at height $z = h$ above the ground.\n\nThe coil passes through a vertically non-uniform, axisymmetric magnetic field given by $\\vec{B}(z) = \\gamma z ~\\hat{z}$, where $\\gamma = 1.50~\\mathrm{T/m}$ is a spatial constant gradient. There is no uniform component of the field. The system is in vacuum and all frictional, air, or mechanical losses except electrical are negligible. On reaching $z=0$, the compact mass gently contacts the ground without bounce and the coil's motion and current subsequently decay freely due to the inductor and resistor; no external forces act on the coil or disk after contact.\n\nAssume standard gravity $g = 9.81~\\mathrm{m/s}^2$. Universal constants: $\\mu_0 = 4\\pi \\times 10^{-7}~\\mathrm{T \\cdot m/A}$, $\\varepsilon_0 = 8.85 \\times 10^{-12}~\\mathrm{F/m}$.\n\nThe initial system is at rest with no current; at the end, both the disk and coil may possess nonzero rotational and translational kinetic energy, while the circuit may still carry current and thus have magnetic energy stored.\n\n\\\\boxed{\\textbf{Calculate the total thermal energy in Joules ($\\mathrm{J}$) dissipated in the coil resistance $R$ from the moment the mass is released at $z=h$ until all coil current has fully decayed to zero at $z=0$, accounting for all electromagnetic induction, rotational and translational kinetic and potential energies, nonuniform $\\vec{B}(z)$, inductor self-energy, rope/disk mechanics, and assuming the mass, disk, rope, and coil have exactly the stated properties. Give your final answer numerically in SI units, boxed.}}",
  "topic_tags": [
    "coupled mechanics",
    "electromagnetic induction",
    "energy conservation",
    "rotational dynamics",
    "LR circuits",
    "advanced mechanics",
    "multi-domain analysis"
  ]
}
